thread.title: Okanagan community refuses motel new operating licence
thread.title_full: Okanagan community refuses motel new operating licence

author: Doris Maria Bregolisse
title: Okanagan community refuses motel new operating licence
text:
February 22, 2017 12:34 am Okanagan community refuses motel new operating licence By Doris Maria Bregolisse Anchor/Reporter Global News 
The owner of the Airport Inn Lakeside in Lake Country, north of Kelowna, B.C., makes a plea to council to vote in favour of issuing his 2017 business licence. Travis Lowe/ Global Okanagan What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' editorial staff without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... X What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... - Listen 
LAKE COUNTRY, B.C. – Council has unanimously voted to refuse the Airport Inn Lakeside a new business permit for 2017. 
Citing compliance issues with the B.C. Building Code and local bylaws, council agreed with the District of Lake Country’s staff report. Former guests of Airport Inn Lakeside speak out 
At Tuesday’s meeting, Airport Inn Lakeside owner Raif Fleihan pleaded with council for his business licence renewal. 
Fleihan told council he wanted to continue working with them, but they refused to allow him to operate with deficiencies. 
Global News learned the Airport Inn Lakeside was having issues with the B.C. Safety Authority in June 2016. 
At that time, electrical issues at the hotel’s site were of concern. 
A former long-term resident of the motel came forward to Global News complaining of bed bug bites he said were acquired during his stay. 
The Airport Inn Lakeside motel was assembled on the Lake Country property in 1993, having been moved from Burtch Road at Harvey Avenue in Kelowna. It used to be known as the Stetson Motel. 
Neighbours complained about the structure to Global News in 1995, saying the site was in disarray. 
The owner made few improvements to the collection of buildings since then, but was working on renovations when Global News returned to the site in 2016. 
At that time, the District of Lake Country put a halt to work as no permits had been issued. 
Fleihan denies the allegations of health and safety infractions. He left Tuesday night’s meeting refusing comment to Global News. © 2017 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.
